Cause.definition: something that brings about an effect or result [the negligent act which was the of the plaintiff's injury] NOTE
Cause.origin: [the negligent act which was the of the plaintiff's injury]

1.definition: to serve as the cause of [the scales struck the plaintiffinjuries for which she sues ", 162 N.E.99 (1928)"]

cause in fact.definition: a cause without which the result would not have occurred called also

concurrent cause.definition: a cause that joins simultaneously with another cause to produce a result called alsocompareandin this entry

2.definition: to effect by command, authority, or force [the administrator shall an investigation to be made]

procuring cause.definition: one (as a broker) that sets in motion a continuous series of events culminating esp. in the sale or leasing of real estate [entitled to a commission as theof the sale even though the listing had expired]
procuring cause.procuring cause: of the sale even though the listing had expired]

pro·duc·ing cause.definition: an efficient, exciting, or contributing cause (as an act, practice, or event) that produces an injury which would not have occurred without it [claimed that the workplace accident was aof his disability] used esp. in workers' compensation and consumer protection cases
pro·duc·ing cause.note: A producing cause lacks the element of foreseeability associated with a proximate cause, being more exclusively concerned with causation in fact.
pro·duc·ing cause.producing cause: of his disability] used esp. in workers' compensation and consumer protection cases

proximate cause.definition: a cause that sets in motion a sequence of events uninterrupted by any superseding causes and that results in a usually foreseeable effect (as an injury) which would not otherwise have occurred called alsosee alsoin the Important Cases section comparein this entry
in the Important Cases section compare

re·mote cause.definition: a cause that is followed by a superseding cause interrupting the chain of causationa cause that in ordinary experience does not lead to a particular effect comparein this entry

su·per·sed·ing cause.definition: an unforeseeable intervening cause that interrupts the chain of causation and becomes the proximate cause of the effect called alsocompareandin this entry

good cause.definition: a substantial reason put forth in good faith that is not unreasonable, arbitrary, or irrational and that is sufficient to create an excuse for an act under the law [unable to showfor failure to pay child support] [neglect of duty isfor removal of a trustee]

3.definition: something (as an event or the exercise of ordinary care or prudence) that excuses or justifies failure to file a tax return on time

suf·fi·cient cause.definition: cause that is deemed enough to provide an excuse under the law

sub_terms.a: in this entry often used in the phrase

3 a.definition: a ground of a legal action [tortious conduct is not a of divorce embraced within the statutory cause of cruel and inhuman treatment ""]

sub_terms.b: [questions of law…determinative of the then pending "R. T. Gerwatowski"]

4.definition: the reason for making a contract comparevt
4.note: Under the Louisiana Civil Code, if a contract's cause is illicit or immoral, the contract is absolutely null. If the cause fails after the contract is made (as when a leased building cannot be occupied because of a fire), the contract may either be not enforced or only partially enforced.
